subject: Cybersecurity
title: The Enigma Machine: Nazi Germany's 'Unbreakable' Code
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Enigma Machine: Nazi Germany's 'Unbreakable' Code usable.

hook.text: Germany built a machine that could encode messages in 159 quintillion different ways. They thought it was perfect.

buildup.text: Enigma used rotating electromechanical rotors to create polyalphabetic substitution at industrial scale.

discovery.text: Each keypress changed the rotor configuration. The same letter never encrypted the same way twice in a row.

twist.text: The flaw: Enigma could never encrypt a letter as itself. That tiny constraint was its undoing.

climax.text: Enigma was brilliant engineering with a fatal design rule that codebreakers exploited.

quiz.question: What was Enigma's key design flaw?
options: A letter could never encrypt as itself
